Her sultry vocals, infectious beats, and catchy hooks made the album a hit worldwide, earning her an MTV Europe Music Award for Best New Act.

Over the next decade, Rihanna continued to evolve as an artist, with her dynamic persona and groundbreaking style captivating millions of fans. Her subsequent albums, "Good Girl Gone Bad" (2007), "Rated R" (2009), and "Loud" (2010), cemented her status as a superstar. Collaborations with artists such as Kanye West, Drake, and Eminem helped push her career to new heights, culminating in her 2011 album, "Talk That Talk," which earned her a Grammy Award for Best Urban Contemporary Album.

Rihanna's entrepreneurial spirit shone brightly in 2013 when she launched Fenty Beauty, a luxury cosmetics brand named after herself. With her keen eye for design and an emphasis on inclusivity and diversity, Fenty Beauty quickly became a global phenomenon and catapulted Rihanna into the fashion and beauty industry.

It's never easy to condense a vibrant personality like Rihanna's into a short biography, but here is an overview:

Rihanna Fenty, known mononymously as Rihanna, was born on February 20, 1988, in Saint Michael, Barbados. She grew up in a loving family with her father, Ronald Fenty, a pastor, and her mother, Christine Evers, a nurse. She was the youngest of three children, with an older brother, Robyn Fenty, and an older sister, Robyn Renée Fenty.

From an early age, Rihanna showed an affinity for music and began writing her own songs. In 2003, she moved to the United States to pursue a career in music. She started by modeling for various fashion brands, such as Guess, before transitioning into the entertainment industry.

In 2005, Rihanna released her self-titled debut album, "Rated R," through Def Jam Recordings. The album featured catchy pop and R&B tracks like "Pon de Replay" and "SOS," which helped her gain significant popularity. The album's title and edgy theme led to the controversy over the "R" rating, but it propelled Rihanna to global success.

Rihanna's subsequent albums, "A Girl Like Me" (2006), "Good Girl Gone Bad" (2007), and "Rated R" (2009), showcased her versatility and evolution as an artist. Her music incorporated various genres, including reggae, pop, and dancehall. Some of her most popular songs include "Umbrella," "Don't Stop the Music," and "Only Girl (In the World)."

In 2011, Rihanna collaborated with rapper Eminem on "Love the Way You Lie," which garnered critical acclaim and a Grammy Award for Best Rap/Sung Collaboration. Her sixth studio album, "Talk That Talk" (2011), produced chart-topping hits like "We Found Love," "Diamonds," and "Cockiness (Love It)."
